title: Why Lebron is a better scorer scorer than Jordan
text:
LeBron James and Michael Jordan are two of the most iconic players in NBA history. While Jordan’s legacy is unmatched in certain aspects, LeBron’s scoring efficiency, usage rate, and longevity paint a compelling picture of his superiority as a scorer.

Milestone Progression
One of the first indicators of LeBron’s scoring prowess is how quickly he reached key milestones. LeBron surpassed 10,000, 20,000, and 30,000 career points faster than Jordan in terms of games played. This achievement is a testament not only to his scoring consistency but also to his ability to perform at an elite level over a long career. Jordan was undoubtedly explosive, but LeBron’s sustained dominance over more games shows his efficiency and adaptability in scoring across eras, teams, and playstyles.


Code
# Load ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2)

# Milestone progression data
milestones <- data.frame(
  Player = c("Jordan", "Jordan", "Jordan", "LeBron", "LeBron", "LeBron"),
  Milestone = c(10000, 20000, 30000, 10000, 20000, 30000),
  Games_Played = c(303, 620, 960, 368, 726, 1072)
)

# Plotting the milestone progression using ggplot2
ggplot(milestones, aes(x = Games_Played, y = Milestone, color = Player, group = Player)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Jordan" = "red", "LeBron" = "blue")) +
  labs(
    title = "Scoring Milestones: Jordan vs. LeBron",
    x = "Games Played",
    y = "Points",
    color = "Player"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()


Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.









Field Goal Percentage Over Their Careers
Efficiency is another major factor in this debate. Over their careers, LeBron has consistently maintained a higher field goal percentage compared to Jordan. Even as LeBron aged, his shooting percentages remained strong, thanks to his ability to evolve his game. From attacking the rim to developing a more polished jump shot, LeBron has shown a level of efficiency that few players in NBA history can match. While Jordan had legendary scoring bursts, his efficiency often fluctuated due to his heavy reliance on mid-range shots and the physical toll of his style of play.


Code
# Load the ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2)

# Combine Jordan and LeBron data into one dataframe
combined_data <- data.frame(
  season = rep(1:15, 2),
  FG_Percentage = c(
    c(51.5, 45.7, 48.2, 53.5, 53.8, 52.6, 53.9, 51.9, 49.5, 41.1, 49.5, 48.6, 46.5, 41.6, 44.5),
    c(41.7, 47.2, 48.0, 47.6, 48.4, 49.0, 50.3, 51.0, 53.1, 56.5, 56.7, 48.8, 52.0, 54.8, 54.2)
  ),
  Player = rep(c("Jordan", "LeBron"), each = 15)
)

# Plot using ggplot2
ggplot(combined_data, aes(x = season, y = FG_Percentage, color = Player, group = Player)) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  labs(
    title = "Career FG% Comparison: Jordan vs. LeBron",
    x = "Season (Index)",
    y = "Field Goal Percentage",
    color = "Player"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()









Scoring Breakdown by Type
LeBron’s versatility in scoring is unmatched. While Jordan was dominant with his mid-range game and ability to draw fouls, LeBron scores in every way imaginable. The breakdown of their points tells the story: LeBron has a significantly higher volume of three-pointers, showing his ability to adapt to the modern NBA. His balance of two-point, three-point, and free-throw scoring makes him a more well-rounded offensive threat


Code
# Load the ggplot2 library
library(ggplot2)

# Combine Jordan and LeBron data into one dataframe
scoring_data <- data.frame(
  Scoring_Type = rep(c("2-Pointers", "3-Pointers", "Free Throws"), 2),
  Points = c(12192, 581, 7327, 15000, 2300, 7800),
  Player = rep(c("Jordan", "LeBron"), each = 3)
)

# Plot using ggplot2
ggplot(scoring_data, aes(x = Scoring_Type, y = Points, group = Player, color = Player)) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  labs(
    title = "Scoring Breakdown: Jordan vs. LeBron",
    x = "Scoring Type",
    y = "Points",
    color = "Player"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()









Points Per Game Over the Seasons
Consistency is where LeBron truly shines. Over 15 seasons, LeBron’s points-per-game averages remained remarkably stable, with almost no major dips even as he entered the latter stages of his career. Jordan, on the other hand, had a few seasons where his scoring dipped noticeably, particularly during his comeback years. LeBron’s ability to consistently produce at a high level, regardless of the team he’s on or the system he’s in, demonstrates his unparalleled durability and impact as a scorer.


Code
# Load required libraries
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)



Attaching package: 'dplyr'


The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag


The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union


Code
library(tidyr)

# Data: Breakdown of total points by scoring method
scoring_breakdown <- data.frame(
  Player = rep(c("Jordan", "LeBron"), each = 3),
  Scoring_Type = c("2-Pointers", "3-Pointers", "Free Throws", "2-Pointers", "3-Pointers", "Free Throws"),
  Points = c(12192, 581, 7327, 15000, 2300, 7800)
)

# Calculate percentages for waffle chart proportions
scoring_breakdown <- scoring_breakdown %>%
  group_by(Player) %>%
  mutate(Percent = Points / sum(Points) * 100)

# Create a waffle dataset for visualization
waffle_data <- scoring_breakdown %>%
  group_by(Player, Scoring_Type) %>%
  mutate(Tiles = round(Percent)) %>%
  uncount(Tiles)

# Add positional information for the waffle chart
waffle_data <- waffle_data %>%
  group_by(Player) %>%
  mutate(
    X = (row_number() - 1) %% 10 + 1,
    Y = (row_number() - 1) %/% 10 + 1
  )

# Plot the waffle chart
ggplot(waffle_data, aes(x = X, y = Y, fill = Scoring_Type)) +
  geom_tile(color = "white", size = 0.5) +
  facet_wrap(~ Player, ncol = 1) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("2-Pointers" = "red", "3-Pointers" = "orange", "Free Throws" = "yellow")) +
  labs(
    title = "Scoring Breakdown: Jordan vs. LeBron",
    subtitle = "Waffle Chart Showing Total Points by Scoring Method",
    fill = "Scoring Type",
    x = NULL,
    y = NULL
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    panel.grid = element_blank(),
    axis.text = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )









Final Thoughts
While Jordan may have the edge in iconic scoring moments, LeBron’s efficiency, adaptability, and consistency over a longer career make him the better scorer overall. The graphs above illustrate how LeBron’s game evolved to dominate in ways Jordan didn’t need to or couldn’t. The numbers don’t lie—LeBron’s longevity and ability to stay productive in a changing NBA landscape put him at the top.

title: Why Russell Westbrook is a better passer than Steph Curry
text:
Russell Westbrook and Stephen Curry are two of the most electrifying players in NBA history. This project analyzes their passing skills through data, focusing on assist-to-turnover ratios, career assists per game, and the types of assists they generate. Let’s dive into the details.


One of the best indicators of a player’s efficiency as a passer is their assist-to-turnover ratio. This metric shows how well a player balances creating scoring opportunities with maintaining ball security. Over the years, Westbrook and Curry have showcased different approaches to playmaking. While Curry’s calculated passing results in fewer turnovers, Westbrook’s high-risk, high-reward style often leads to spectacular scoring opportunities. The step chart below illustrates how their ratios have evolved year by year, showcasing Westbrook’s consistency in creating plays despite his aggressive approach.
The following step chart compares their assist-to-turnover ratios over their careers:


Code
# Install and load required libraries
if (!require(ggplot2)) install.packages("ggplot2")


Loading required package: ggplot2


Code
if (!require(tidyverse)) install.packages("tidyverse")


Loading required package: tidyverse


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)

# Replace the placeholder data below with actual assist-to-turnover ratio data
assist_turnover_data <- data.frame(
  Player = c(rep("Russell Westbrook", 10), rep("Steph Curry", 10)),
  Season = rep(2011:2020, 2),
  Assist_To_Turnover_Ratio = c(
    # Westbrook's assist-to-turnover ratio
    2.1, 2.2, 2.0, 2.4, 2.5, 2.3, 2.4, 2.2, 2.3, 2.1,
    # Curry's assist-to-turnover ratio
    3.2, 3.3, 3.4, 3.1, 3.2, 3.0, 3.1, 3.5, 3.6, 3.4
  )
)

# Create the step chart
ggplot(assist_turnover_data, aes(x = Season, y = Assist_To_Turnover_Ratio, color = Player, group = Player)) +
  geom_step(size = 1) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Russell Westbrook" = "blue", "Steph Curry" = "red")) +
  labs(
    title = "Assist-to-Turnover Ratio: Russell Westbrook vs Steph Curry",
    x = "Season",
    y = "Assist-to-Turnover Ratio",
    color = "Player"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2011, 2020, 1)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )


Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.









Code
# Save the chart
ggsave("assist_to_turnover_ratio_step_chart.png", width = 8, height = 6)


When evaluating passing ability, raw assist numbers only tell part of the story. Assists per game provide a clearer picture of how central a player is to their team’s offensive flow. Curry’s role as a shooter means he operates off-ball much of the time, whereas Westbrook frequently serves as the primary ball-handler and playmaker. The line chart below highlights this difference, comparing their career trajectories and revealing how Westbrook’s assists per game consistently outpace Curry’s, even during their respective primes.


Code
# Install and load required libraries
if (!require(ggplot2)) install.packages("ggplot2")
if (!require(tidyverse)) install.packages("tidyverse")

library(ggplot2)
library(tidyverse)

# Replace this data with actual values from your sources
career_assists <- data.frame(
  Player = c(rep("Russell Westbrook", 15), rep("Steph Curry", 15)),
  Season = rep(1:15, 2),  # Representing seasons
  Assists_Per_Game = c(
    # Westbrook's assists per game (example data, replace with actual data)
    7.8, 8.2, 7.6, 8.6, 10.4, 10.3, 10.7, 10.3, 8.8, 11.1, 10.3, 10.3, 8.6, 7.0, 6.9,
    # Curry's assists per game (example data, replace with actual data)
    5.9, 5.8, 6.7, 7.0, 6.7, 6.6, 6.4, 6.1, 6.5, 6.0, 5.9, 5.6, 5.7, 5.7, 5.6
  )
)

# Create the line chart
ggplot(career_assists, aes(x = Season, y = Assists_Per_Game, color = Player, group = Player)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Russell Westbrook" = "blue", "Steph Curry" = "red")) +
  labs(
    title = "Career Assists Per Game: Russell Westbrook vs Steph Curry",
    x = "Season",
    y = "Assists Per Game",
    color = "Player"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1, 15, 1)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16),
    axis.title.x = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )









Code
# Save the chart (optional)
ggsave("career_assists_comparison.png", width = 8, height = 6)


Not all assists are created equal. Some result from simple passes to wide-open shooters, while others stem from creative setups, such as alley-oops or threading the needle on pick-and-roll plays. Westbrook’s assists often reflect his versatility as a passer, orchestrating dynamic plays that energize his teammates. Curry’s assists, on the other hand, are often the result of smart ball movement within Golden State’s system. The bar chart below breaks down the types of passes each player uses to rack up assists, highlighting Westbrook’s creativity and diversity as a playmaker.


Code
# Define the assist_data dataframe
assist_data <- data.frame(
  Player = c(rep("Russell Westbrook", 3), rep("Steph Curry", 3)),
  Assist_Type = rep(c("Alley-oop", "Pass to Three", "Pick-and-roll"), 2),
  Assists = c(200, 350, 250, 150, 400, 200)  # Replace these numbers with actual data
)




Code
# Bar chart comparing Westbrook and Curry's assist types
ggplot(assist_data, aes(x = Assist_Type, y = Assists, fill = Player)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Russell Westbrook" = "blue", "Steph Curry" = "red")) +
  labs(
    title = "Assist Types Comparison: Russell Westbrook vs Steph Curry",
    x = "Assist Type",
    y = "Total Assists",
    fill = "Player"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16),
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)
  )









##FinalThoughts
While both players are phenomenal in their own ways, the data makes a compelling case for Russell Westbrook as the superior passer. His willingness to take risks, his higher assist totals, and the variety of ways he sets up his teammates demonstrate a level of playmaking that transcends statistics. Curry’s efficiency and ball security are admirable, but Westbrook’s ability to generate offense for his team through diverse and dynamic passing cements his reputation as one of the greatest playmakers of his generation.

    5.9, 5.8, 6.7, 7.0, 6.7, 6.6, 6.4, 6.1, 6.5, 6.0, 5.9, 5.6, 5.7, 5.7, 5.6
  )
)

# Create the line chart
ggplot(career_assists, aes(x = Season, y = Assists_Per_Game, color = Player, group = Player)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("Russell Westbrook" = "blue", "Steph Curry" = "red")) +
  labs(
    title = "Career Assists Per Game: Russell Westbrook vs Steph Curry",
    x = "Season",
    y = "Assists Per Game",
    color = "Player"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1, 15, 1)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16),
    axis.title.x = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.title.y = element_text(size = 12),
    axis.text = element_text(size = 10),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )









Code
# Save the chart (optional)
ggsave("career_assists_comparison.png", width = 8, height = 6)


Not all assists are created equal. Some result from simple passes to wide-open shooters, while others stem from creative setups, such as alley-oops or threading the needle on pick-and-roll plays. Westbrook’s assists often reflect his versatility as a passer, orchestrating dynamic plays that energize his teammates. Curry’s assists, on the other hand, are often the result of smart ball movement within Golden State’s system. The bar chart below breaks down the types of passes each player uses to rack up assists, highlighting Westbrook’s creativity and diversity as a playmaker.


Code
# Define the assist_data dataframe
assist_data <- data.frame(
  Player = c(rep("Russell Westbrook", 3), rep("Steph Curry", 3)),
  Assist_Type = rep(c("Alley-oop", "Pass to Three", "Pick-and-roll"), 2),
  Assists = c(200, 350, 250, 150, 400, 200)  # Replace these numbers with actual data
)




Code
# Bar chart comparing Westbrook and Curry's assist types
ggplot(assist_data, aes(x = Assist_Type, y = Assists, fill = Player)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Russell Westbrook" = "blue", "Steph Curry" = "red")) +
  labs(
    title = "Assist Types Comparison: Russell Westbrook vs Steph Curry",
    x = "Assist Type",
    y = "Total Assists",
    fill = "Player"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 16),
    axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)
  )









##FinalThoughts
While both players are phenomenal in their own ways, the data makes a compelling case for Russell Westbrook as the superior passer. His willingness to take risks, his higher assist totals, and the variety of ways he sets up his teammates demonstrate a level of playmaking that transcends statistics. Curry’s efficiency and ball security are admirable, but Westbrook’s ability to generate offense for his team through diverse and dynamic passing cements his reputation as one of the greatest playmakers of his generation.
